block.p: Red Suspenders

Roger B. Swain, the man with the red suspenders and the down-home manner who exhibits his indefatigable store of horticultural knowledge on PBS's ''Victory Garden,'' will make an appearance in Roxbury's Town Hall at 11 a.m. Thursday.

He will deliver a talk on ''The Gardener as Supermodel'' and will be available for informal conversation during a box lunch afterward. Mr. Swain is also the science editor of Horticulture Magazine, a biologist, writer and -- as his television fans know -- an entertaining storyteller.
Red Suspenders

Roger B. Swain, the man with the red suspenders and the down-home manner who exhibits his indefatigable store of horticultural knowledge on PBS's ''Victory Garden,'' will make an appearance in Roxbury's Town Hall at 11 a.m. Thursday.

He will deliver a talk on ''The Gardener as Supermodel'' and will be available for informal conversation during a box lunch afterward. Mr. Swain is also the science editor of Horticulture Magazine, a biologist, writer and -- as his television fans know -- an entertaining storyteller.
Proceeds from the $45 tickets to the lecture and lunch will benefit the Rivers Alliance of Connecticut, dedicated to protecting the state's watersheds, rivers and streams.
The program is sponsored by the Roxbury-Bridgewater Garden Club. The numbers to call for more information, directions or reservations are (860) 355-3959 or (860) 210-0397.
Jazz and Picnicking

Put together a picnic, find something to sit on and take it all to a jazz concert with Vincent Lyn today in Woodbridge. The music is in the spirit of the old Monterey Cafe where many jazz greats including Nat (King) Cole and Josephine Baker performed. Delores Greenlee, daughter of the cafe's founder, will be on hand to talk about the historic black jazz club in its heyday. The event is sponsored by CARP, a supportive housing program for people with AIDS, and by Willie Ruff, the musician and Yale faculty member. It will be held at the Harold Ince residence on Rimmon Road, from noon to 5 p.m. Admission is $20. The number to call for directions is (203) 387-2829.
Ceramics to Fiber to Metal

Expo 2000, the 43rd annual show of the Guilford Handcraft Center, will be held Thursday through Saturday from noon to 9 p.m. on the Guilford green. Admission will be $5, free for children under 13. More than 160 artists will offer museum-quality ceramics, wood, basketry, fiber, jewelry, glass and metal in one of the largest juried shows in the state. In addition, severl craft demonstrations will be in progress throughout the show, along with an exhibition by the center's faculty and some of its 3,500 students.

Walking tours of buildings surrounding the green will be offered daily, and a performance by the former state troubadour, Mike Kachuba, will be presented on Thursday at 1:30 p.m. Other entertainment includes Chinese fan dancing for children on Friday at 4 p.m. and the New Haven Morris and Sword Dancers on Saturday at 7 p.m. Storytellers will be at the north end of the green daily from noon to 7 p.m.
Books, Books, Books

A six-day book sale is scheduled at the New Canaan Public Library, 151 Elm Street, beginning on Friday from 5:30 to 8 p.m., when browsers will be treated to refreshments and music as well as first pick of the books, cassettes and records. There is no admission charge.

Hours on Saturday will be from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. and refreshments will again be offered. Everything will be discounted by 25 percent on July 17, and by 50 percent on July 18. Hours on both days will be 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.
A donation will be requested on July 19 and 20, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., when whatever is left may be taken for free. The number to call for more information is (203) 801-2665.
Playwrights at Work

The annual National Playwrights Summer Conference has begun at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford. Scripts in hand, professional actors guided by professional directors perform staged readings of the works as they develop new plays by American and international writers before an audience.

''Parts Unknown,'' by Ron Fitzgerald, opened the series yesterday. John Henry Redwood's work about the rape of a black woman by a white man, will be shown today at 2:30, and Jerome Hairston's ''A.M. Sunday,'' about an interracial couple, will be seen Tuesday and Thursday at 8:30. A boys' boarding school in Philadelphia during the McCarthy era is the backdrop of ''The Square Root of Minus One,'' by Peter Morris. It will be performed on Friday at 8:30 and Saturday at 2:30 p.m.
''Skitaletz'' (''The Wanderer''), by Dmitry Lipkin, is a comic fable that will be playing on Friday at 8:30 and Saturday at 2:30.
''The Home Life of Polar Bears,'' by Hilly Hicks Jr., is about a family preparing to be profiled on ''60 Minutes''; it's scheduled for Saturday at 8:30 and next Sunday at 2:30.
The center is at 305 Great Neck Road. The number to call for tickets ($8 to $12) and directions is (860) 443-5378.
ELEANOR CHARLES
